facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 369 to 375 of 1967 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 369 to 375 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated October 15, 1966 of Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1475, 1479, 1480 of 1965, and 119, 120, 122, 125 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated October 15, 1966 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1475, 1479, and 1480 of 1965, and 119, 120, 12.2 and 125 of 1966 respectively.

facts.text: Appellants are owners of lands situated at Ranoli, District Baroda.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the owners of the lands in question situate at Ranoli, District Baroda.

facts.text: 3rd respondent Company owns about 140 acres of land in Ranoli village.

anchor.surface_text: The 3rd respondent Company also owns about 140 acres of land in the same village.

facts.text: Appellants' lands are adjacent to or enclaves surrounded by Company's lands and railway lines.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants lands are either situate adjacent to and between the Companys lands and the railway lines or are enclaves surrounded by lands belonging to the Company.

facts.text: State Government issued notification under sec. 4 on July 22, 1961 for public purpose of fertilizer factory.

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1961 the State Government issued a numberification under sec. 4 of the Act to the effect that the appellants said lands were or were likely to be needed for a public purpose,, viz., for a fertilizer factory.

facts.text: Notification of July 22, 1961 was withdrawn on September 11, 1961 as lands unsuitable for factory.

anchor.surface_text: That numberification was withdrawn on September 11, 1961 as the lands were stated to be unsuitable for such a factory.

facts.text: Fresh notification under sec. 4 issued on September 12, 1961 for purpose of 3rd respondent Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Government however issued the very next day a fresh numberification under sec. 4 in respect of the same lands, this time for the purpose of the 3rd respondent Company.

facts.text: Some appellants filed writ petitions challenging September 12, 1961 notification.

anchor.surface_text: Some of these appellants thereupon filed writ petitions challenging its validity.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered decision in first Arora Case.

anchor.surface_text: While these petitions were pending before the High Court this Court delivered its decision in what is known as the first Arora Case 1 .

facts.text: Amendment Act XXXI of 1962 brought into force from July 20, 1962 with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: To get over the difficulties arising from that decision, first an Ordinance and then the Amendment Act XXXI of 1962, were passed. The Amendment Act was brought into force from July 20, 1962 with retrospective effect.

facts.text: Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules made under sec. 55, brought into force June 22, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government thereafter made Rules under sec. 55 of the Act called the Land Acquisition  Companies  Rules which were brought into force from June 22, 1963.

facts.text: State Government withdrew notification dated September 12, 1961 on July 24, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On July 24, 1963 the State Government withdrew the numberification dated September 12, 1961 whereupon the writ petitions filed by the appellants challenging the said numberifications were withdrawn.

facts.text: D.K. Master, Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda, started inquiry under Rule 4.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime one D.K. Master, who was then the Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda, started an inquiry under Rule 4 of the said Rules.

facts.text: State Government issued sec. 4 notification on August 28, 1964 stating lands needed for 3rd respondent Company's factory.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28,1964 the State Government issued a numberification under  1  1962 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 149A.I.R. 1962 S.C. 764. sec. 4 stating that the appellants said lands were needed or were likely to be needed for the establishment of a factory of the 3rd respondent Company.

facts.text: Appellants filed objections under sec. 5A, which were rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed their objections in the inquiry then held under sec. 5A but they were rejected.

facts.text: State Government issued sec. 6 notification on October 18, 1965 declaring lands needed for Company's factory manufacturing optical bleaching agents, intermediate dye-stuffs etc., as public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1965 the State Government issued sec. 6 numberification declaring that the said lands were needed for the factory of the 3rd respondent Company which it was stated was taking steps or en,gaging itself for manufacture of optical bleaching agents, interme- diate dye-stuffs etc., which according to the Government was for a public purpose.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions challenging notifications of August 28, 1964 and October 18, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon filed writ petitions from which these appeals arise challenging the two numberifications dated August 28, 1964 and October 18, 1965 respectively.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat dismissing the writ petitions filed by the appellants

facts.text: D.K. Master worked as Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda from December 6, 1961 to April 29, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit of Master establishes that he worked as a Sp. A. officer at Baroda from December 6, 1961 to April 29 1965.

facts.text: Master appointed to officiate as Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda on February 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1963 he was appointed to officiate as Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda.

facts.text: Government letter dated October 1, 1963 to Master forwarding Company's application dated September 11, 1963 and directing inquiry under Rules.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1. 1963 the Government wrote a letter to him forwarding the application dated September 11, 1963 of the 3rd respondent Company requesting the Government to acquire the lands in question and directing him to hold an inquiry according to the said Rules and to make a report.

facts.text: Notification dated October 11, 1963 authorizing Special Land Acquisition Officers to perform functions of Collector under sec. 3(c).

anchor.surface_text: On October 11, 1963 the Government issued another numberification superseding the numberification of October 1, 1963 and authorising all Special Land Acquisition Officers in the State to perform the functions of the Collector under the Act within the area of their respective jurisdiction.

facts.text: Master issued notices to 27 owners on October 22, 1963; 10 appeared and statements recorded on October 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On October 22, 1963 he issued numberices to 27 owners of the lands proposed to be acquired but only 10 of them appeared before him and he recorded their statements on October 31, 1963.

facts.text: Company owns 140 acres: 48 acres ravine lands unfit for factory, to be used for housing 700 workmen and amenities; 40 acres used for factories, warehouses; balance 60 acres not compact, contain appellants' pockets.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Company owns. 140 acres of land. But as the affidavit of the Companys officer shows out of these 140 acres 48 acres are ravine lands, unfit as factory sites. According to the Company, those lands however will be utilised for housing accommodation for its 700 workmen and for amenities for them such as play grounds, a sports club. a recreation centre and a companyoperative companysumer society. Forty acres out of, the rest of the land have already been used for companystructing some of the factories warehouses and godowns. As regards the balance of 60 acres, they do number form a companypact block and companytain in them small pockets belonging to the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants alleged acquisition mala fide and without application of mind.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the appellants companytended that the pro- cedure laid down in the said Land Acquisition  Companies  Rules was number followed, that the purpose for which the acquisition was being made was number a public purpose within the meaning of sec. 40 1  a , that the acquisition was made mala fide and in companyourable exercise of power,

facts.text: Court held Master's inquiry and report under Rule 4 valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, numberobjection to the appointment of Master to perform the functions of the Collector under sec. 3 c  or to his companypetence to make the inquiry and the report under Rule 4 or their legality can be validly made

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: As numbere of them can be upheld the appeals have to be dismissed.

arguments.claim: out of these 140 acres 48 acres are ravine lands unfit as factory sites ... will be utilised for housing ... Forty acres ... used ... balance of 60 acres ... do not form a compact block and contain ... pockets belonging to the appellants ... unless these pockets are acquired ... not possible to use them as factory site

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Company owns. 140 acres of land. But as the affidavit of the Companys officer shows out of these 140 acres 48 acres are ravine lands, unfit as factory sites. According to the Company, those lands however will be utilised for housing accommodation for its 700 workmen and for amenities for them such as play grounds, a sports club. a recreation centre and a cooperative consumer society.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Collector within, their respective areas. It is true that the numberification also declares that such of the Sp. L.A. officers as may be appointed in

arguments.court_reasoning: Explains need for acquisition

arguments.claim: Section 3(c) defines a Collector to mean ... and includes ... any officer specially appointed by the Government to perform the functions of a Collector under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 3(c) defines a Collector to mean Collector of the District and includes Deputy Commissioner and any officer specially appointed by the Government to perform the functions of a Collector under the Act.

arguments.claim: Section 20 of the General Clauses Act ... provides that ... the expressions used in such rules ... shall have the same meaning as in the Central Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 20 of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897 provides that where a Central Act empowers making rules, the expressions used in such rules, if made after the commencement of that Act shall have the same meaning as in the Central Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context.

arguments.claim: the word Collector must have the same meaning in the rules as in sec. 3(c)

anchor.surface_text: There being nothing repugnant in the subject or context, the word Collector must have the same meaning in the rules as in sec. 3(c) which includes an officer specially appointed to perform the functions of the Collector.

arguments.claim: those words simply mean that ... he has to be specially appointed ... The word specially has therefore reference to the special purpose of appointment and is not used to convey the sense of a special as against a general appointment

anchor.surface_text: In our view, those words simply mean that as such an officer is not a Collector and cannot perform the functions of a Collector under the Act, he has to be specially appointed, that is appointed for the specific purpose of performing those functions. The word specially has therefore reference to the special purpose of appointment

arguments.claim: sec. 15 of the General Clauses Act provides that where a Central Act empowers an authority to appoint a person ... such power can be exercised either by name or by virtue of office

anchor.surface_text: Besides, sec. 15 of the General Clauses Act provides that where a Central Act empowers an authority to appoint a person to perform a certain function, such power can be exercised either by name or by virtue of office.

arguments.claim: in the context of sec. 3(c) when an officer is authorised to perform the functions of the Collector it means that he is appointed to perform those functions

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Sanghi argued that even so the notification did not appoint Master but merely authorised him to perform the Collectors functions. In our View, the distinction is without difference. In the context of sec. 3(c) when an officer is authorised to perform the functions of the Collector it means that he is appointed

arguments.claim: Rule 4 ... provides that the officer conducting the inquiry has to hear the Company before making his report

anchor.surface_text: The Rule however provides that the officer conducting the inquiry has to hear the Company before making his report. Whether he has also to hear the owners of the land or not need not be decided

arguments.claim: We do not find anything in Rule 4 or in any other Rule to warrant such a proposition

anchor.surface_text: We do not find anything in Rule 4 or in any other Rule to warrant such a proposition. The inquiry, the report to be made subsequent upon such inquiry, obtaining the opinion of the Land Acquisition Committee, all these are intended to enable the Government to come to a tentative conclusion

holdings.text: No objection to the appointment of Master to perform the functions of the Collector under sec. 3(c) or to his competence to make the inquiry and the report under Rule 4 or their legality can be validly made

anchor.surface_text: In our view, no objection to the appointment of Master to perform the functions of the Collector under sec. 3 c  or to his competence to make the inquiry and the report under Rule 4 or their legality can be validly made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Master specially appointed via notifications; 'Collector' in rules same as s3(c) per GCA s20; authorisation equates to appointment; directed to inquire and report

holdings.text: The consent given by the State Government was validly given in compliance with Part VII and notifications under ss.4 and 6 validly issued

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the consent given by the State Government for initiating acquisition proceedings was validly given and was in compliance with the provisions of Part VII of the Act and the State Government could validly issue the impugned notifications.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from valid Rule 4 report and s3(c) compliance

holdings.text: The word 'Collector' in Rule 4 has the same meaning as in s.3(c), including specially appointed officer

anchor.surface_text: There being nothing repugnant in the subject or context, the word Collector must have the same meaning in the rules as in sec. 3 c  which includes an officer specially appointed to perform the functions of the Collector.

holdings.reasoning_summary: GCA s20 applies definitions from Act to rules unless repugnant

holdings.text: 'Specially appointed' refers to appointment for specific purpose of performing Collector's functions, not individual vs general

anchor.surface_text: In our view, those words simply mean that as such an officer is not a Collector and cannot perform the functions of a Collector under the Act, he has to be specially appointed, that is appointed for the specific purpose of performing those functions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive reading; GCA s15 allows appointment by office

holdings.text: Authorisation to perform Collector's functions equates to appointment under s.3(c)

anchor.surface_text: In the context of sec. 3 c  when an officer is authorised to perform the functions of the Collector it means that he is appointed to perform those functions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No distinction between appoint/authorise in context; no separate post contemplated

holdings.text: Appellants failed to establish mala fides or non-application of mind by State Government
holdings.reasoning_summary: Vague pleas; govt considered reports; prior withdrawal shows independence; company's land explained
